The forgotten subject

By James Bithell

Ed Scoobie-Would looks at the role of black people in Victorian Art

Apocalypse Now?

Is the apocalypse painter John Martin making a comeback via Tate Britain's new Exhibition? Sarah Jilani investigates

What not to read

Arts at York

Nouse has compiled a taster of some societies to watch out for - find them and many more at Freshers' Fair and sign up for your year-long Arts fix

The Lure of the Library

Since April of this year, 415 public libraries have either already been closed, or faced imminent threat. Just what is it that lured people into libraries, and can they still mean something to us today?

The Movements: Pop Art

Irony, parody and mass culture decorate the altar of this style, while modernism, 'elitist' art and any subculture that takes itself too seriously lies ripped to shreds by its discerning and satirical tone

Jake & Dinos Chapman

Brothers Jake and Dinos Chapman have an exhibition currently spread across both of White Cube's London galleries. Shock here has the ability to expose, rather than simply create an aesthetic reaction.

Lucian Freud dies aged 88

Celebrated German-British artist Lucian Freud has died aged 88 in his London home (Thumbnail credit Lucian Freud: Self Portrait, Reflection [2002]. Image: freeparking via Flickr)

The Importance of Being Earnest

<em>The Importance of Being Earnest</em> is a fine production to end the year on; it should be recommended to those who have not seen the play before, yet it still offers something to those already familiar with the script

Paul Theroux

By James Bithell

Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to Paul Theroux at the Hay Literary Festival on the alluring relationship between travel and fiction

Highlights of Hay Literary Festival

By James Bithell

Gilbert & George, Taryn Simon & Simon Baker, and Rob Lowe

Down The Road

Lyndon Ashmore checked out the up and coming philosophy festival nearby: How The Light Gets In

A Friendship Facialised

By James Bithell

Photographer John Minihan talks to Sarah Jilani about his latest exhibition, his friendship with Samuel Beckett, and the stories that live behind the image (Thumbnail credit All photos: John Minihan)

In Pictures: Travel Photography

By James Bithell

Summer and travel are practically synonymous for many; we take look at inspiring travel photos that can get anyone reaching for their backpack

Broccoli Trees

By James Bithell

Emily Heggadon investigates artists creating artwork solely in the medium of food

Editor's Picks

Oscar Wilde's 1895 comedy, <strong>The Importance of Being Earnest</strong> in Week 9 finishes off a diverse and successful summer term at the Barn...

Stars on Broadway

A spectre is haunting Broadway. Bringing huge status and gargantuan salaries, but sometimes poor performances, it is easy to see the inclusion of film stars and veteran actors in Broadway and West End shows as merely a populist move

Treasure Island

PantSoc's 2011 summer pantomime has a big, energetic cast and genuinely entertaining moments, which make you really want to discount the rather freewheeling storyline and the one-too-many deliberately groan inducing puns

Red Snow

The discordant and the beautiful set the stage at the Barn this week with James Robert Ball's debut musical. Emily Heggadon urges you to see this piece of student written theatre of the highest calibre. Rating: ****

Road

Though to coin the production as merely "different" could be seen as ambiguous and degrading, it shows how <em>Road</em> is very much a breath of fresh air, and through its novelty promenade nature, has created a highly successful performance

Much Ado About Nothing

A production that has you in its frivolous, funny and intelligent grasp from beginning to end, <em>Much Ado About Nothing</em> is undoubtedly one of the highlights of The Globe's 2011 season (Thumbnail credit Image: Tristram Kenton)

WINK

This year the Norman Rea gallery has invited York students to submit work which is intended as a wink or nod towards another artist: an intelligent pastiche that reinterprets, reinvents or reveals an interesting element of the original work

A Midsummer Night's Dream

It cannot be said that after spending an evening in the surprising space that is the drama barn, you are left feeling as if it were merely an illusion. This production of William Shakespeare's <em>A Midsummer Night's Dream</em> was funny and chic, and most certainly concretely ingrained in the minds of the audience (Thumbnail credit Image: Greg Ebdon)

Sensory Steps

Choreographer at the Royal Ballet, Alastair Marriott, talks to <em>Sarah Jilani</em> about music, movement, and the creative process behind his work Sensorium

Natural Progression

Musicians have recently more than ever been jumping from one art form to another. <em>Emily Heggadon</em> explores the rate of success and failure amongst our daring songsters

In Pictures: Lady Macbeth

By James Bithell

Macbeth has recently come to the Royal Opera House: we take a look at portrayals of the ill-fated Lady Macbeth through the ages

Deputy Editor's Picks

Shakespeare's <strong>A Midsummer Night's Dream</strong> comes to the barn this week. Directed by Rosie Fletcher, this iconic and much parodied tale of love, deceit, fairies and asses, faces the challenge of creating something innovative

Turn the page: we should embrace eBooks

Believe me, I love the feel of a good book as much as the next man. As for the moving shelf paraphernalia in the JB Morrell north rooms, it's difficult to guage my excitement

Art

The Barn's latest production, a performance of <em>Art</em> by Yasmina Reza, did not live up to the comedy it promised, and fell short of the play's high critical acclaim. Rating: **

Open Drama Night

Last night at the Drama Barn's Open Drama Night, the Drama Society showcased two student-written plays back-to-back: <em>Just Kids</em> by Thomas Meerstadt and <em>The Name of the Power that Moves You</em> by Hamish Todd
